## Summary

* Approximate Bayesian inference method combining Laplace approximations and adaptive Gauss-Hermite quadrature 
* Motivated by an evidence synthesis model for small-area estimation of HIV indicators in sub-Saharan Africa
* Implemented as a part of the `aghq` R package, allowing flexible use for any model with a `TMB` C++ user template

<!-- 38761C -->

## The Naomi HIV model

* District-level model of HIV indicators synthesising data from household surveys, antenatal care (ANC) clincs, and routine service provision of antiretroviral therapy (ART) [@eaton2021naomi]
* Yearly estimation process: model run interactively by country teams using the web-app `naomi.unaids.org`
* Inference conducted in minutes using empirical Bayes (EB) and a Gaussian approximation via Template Model Builder `TMB` [@kristensen2016tmb]
* Would take days to get accurate answers with MCMC via `tmbstan` [@monnahan2018no]
* Motivates looking for a fast, approximate approach

## Extended latent Gaussian models

* Three stage hierarchical model with observations $y$, latent field $x$ and hyperparameters $\theta$
* In a latent Gaussian model (LGM) [@rue2009approximate] the conditional mean depends on exactly one structured additive predictor $\mu_i = g(\eta_i)$ with $g: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$
  * The `R-INLA` implementation of integrated nested Laplace approximations applies only to LGMs
* Extended latent Gaussian models (ELGM) remove this requirement such that $\mu_i = g(\eta_{\mathcal{J_i}})$ where $g_i: \mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{J_i}|} \to \mathbb{R}$
* Naomi is an ELGM, not an LGM, because we model:
  * ANC indicators offset from household survey indicators
  * Incidence as depending on prevalence and ART coverage
  * Observed data as aggregated finer processes
  * Individuals as possibly attending ART clinics outside their home district
* ELGM precision matrices less sparse than those of LGMs

## Inference procedure

* Laplace approximation: Integrate out variables using a Gaussian approximation to the denominator
$$
p(\theta, y) \approx \tilde p_\text{LA}(\theta, y) = \frac{p(y, x, \theta)}{\tilde p_\text{G}(x \, | \, \theta, y)} \Big\rvert_{x = \hat x(\theta)}
$$
where $\tilde p_\text{G}(x \, | \, \theta, y) = \mathcal{N}(x \, | \, \hat x(\theta), \mathbf{H}(\theta)^{-1})$
* Adaptive Gauss-Hermite Quadrature:
$$
\int_\Theta p(\theta) \text{d} \theta \approx \lvert L \rvert \sum_{z \in \mathcal{Q}(m, k)} p(\hat \theta + Lz) \omega(z)
$$
where the Gauss-Hermite quadrature rule $z \in \mathcal{Q}(m, k)$ is adapted based upon the mode $\hat \theta = \text{argmax}_{\theta \in \Theta} p(\theta)$ and lower Cholesky $LL^\top = - \partial_\theta^2 \log p(\theta) \rvert_{\theta = \hat \theta}$ of the target
* Given a C++ user template for $- \log p(y, x, \theta)$ our algorithm is summarized by Figure 1


* $\text{dim}(x)$ is 491 and $\text{dim}(\theta)$ is 24
* Figure \@ref(fig:fig2) illustrates example model outputs: HIV prevalence, ART coverage, HIV incidence, and number of new infections, at the district level

```{r fig3, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='100%', fig.cap='Inference reults and ECDF comparison for one $x_i$.'}

```

* Compare inferences from `TMB`, `aghq`, `adam` and `tmbstan` using Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) tests on hyperparameter, latent field, and output posterior marginals
* Figure \@ref(fig:fig3) illustrates the ECDF difference between `TMB` and `adam` to `tmbstan` for one particular node in the model

## Future directions

* Scaling up the hyperparameter grid beyond EB
  * Any dense grid would be $k^{24}$ i.e. impractical
  * Sparse grids? Good subspaces of $\mathbb{R}^{24}$?
* Add Laplace matrix algebra approximations [@wood2020simplified]
* More comprehensive inference comparison e.g. maximum mean discrepancy, Pareto-smoothed importance sampling
